captions.text: Alright everybody hold on just one second... one minute. Before you douse yourself with ice water and then share it on Facebook for all your friends to see.
Why don't we take a step back. Are we really sharing awareness right now or are we simply sharing wetness.
Why don't we take a minute and actually talk about ALS.
*guitar and strings with light percussion*
ALS is short for Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis a fatal neurodegenerative disease.
It also goes by the name Lou Gehrig's Disease after the famous baseball player who succumbed to it in 1941.
The disease attacks victims' spinal chords and motor neurons that control movements like raising a hand...
As these neurons slowly degenerate they weaken and then paralyze the body until swallowing and even breathing become impossible.
Though ALS is very damaging to the body, it doesn't effect the victim's other senses or intelligence.
Take for example Stephen Hawking one of the greatest minds of our time
Who continues to theorize on general relativity years after diagnosis.
ALS is frightening because the disease can attack anyone and has no known cause.
It occurs all around the world with no racial or economic barriers...
It has no cure and victims usually live only two to five years after diagnosis.
And sadly while we have almost wiped out Polio and Measles since the 1930s.
There has been little advancement in ALS treatment in that same time.
But ALS is extremely rare effecting only about two out of every one hundred thousand people.
And today scientists are testing new drugs, conducting stem cell research, and exploring the possibility of replacing the attacked motor neurons.
All of which could hopefully lead to a cure.
So now that you know you can go ahead and douse yourself.
But if you live in a place with a drought... you know, try not to waste water.

title: What To Know About ALS Before You Take The Ice Bucket Challenge

Oh and if i would have to do it i would count that one time when i fell 
into a water stream, it was pretty wide gap and almost 8 pm when i fell in 
i saw this grassy thing often seen in waters so i grabed it and climbed 
up(my friend were there but just a little bit away in the forest) when i 
came my friend stood on the other side and asked "are you fine!" I awnsered 
yes so we walked along the water stream until we came to a bridge and 
walked home later on when we were at his place and he turned on the light i 
saw how my hands was covered in blood but i couldnt feel the pain because 
of the cold (it was winter) when i later came home and took a shower the 
pain started to effect and almost all my body parts were frozen cold. So a 
little i know almost how it feels but i think just the fingers and toes got 
paralyzed still i hope they will find the cure as fast as possible﻿

comments.author: Iyhgbhrc

comments.text:
They nicknamed ALS "Lou Gehrig's Disease" so people would know what it was. 
Lou Gehrig was an amazing baseball player in the 20's and 30's. He was 
someone just about everybody knew, so when he was diagnosed with ALS, and 
after his famous, "Some people say I've gotten a bad break, but today I 
consider myself the luckiest man on the face of the earth" speech, the ALS 
Foundation decided it would be a good idea to have Lou be the name and face 
of this terrible disease to raise awareness. He held a lot of records, and 
when he was in high school, during a game played at what's now Wrigley 
Field, he hit a grand-slam out of *a major league stadium!* He was, by all 
accounts, a really nice guy. He undoubtedly would've set more records, and 
broken his own if ALS hadn't taken his life at 37.﻿

comments.author: Jay Young

comments.text:
+Donna Manning  Well, there's at least 2 of us who prefer animals to 
people! We - my husband Larry and I - have a chihuahua/Jack Russell terrier 
mix named Carly and even though she's a dip, she's the best thing that's 
happened to us since our daughter, Lindsey almost 20 years ago! I put her 
in the shower to bathe her yesterday. She's so fluffy and sweet smelling 
today and she's happy to be clean! (She wasn't crazy about the shower, but 
it was easier for me! LOL!) Thanks, Donna!  Sue
comments.author: Lady Suzette

comments.text:
I'm with you, Sue. That's the main reason I'm a vegetarian. I actually 
prefer animals to humans because of the obsessive factor. Enough already! 
There are some deadly diseases out there that ensure a very cruel, slow 
death. Scleroderma causes the skin to toughen up like plastic and then goes 
for the organs. There's another one that causes the body to become like a 
statue, little by little, frozen, and then it gets to the organs. I don't 
see anybody getting behind these. Sure ALS is a horrible disease, but how 
many millions does it get before people spread their money around to other 
less known diseases. I think the ice bucket challenge is just another fad 
that people are rallying around, like the cinnamon challenge. Society likes 
to rally around stuff, and this is just one of them.
comments.author: Donna Manning

comments.text:
+Donna Manning Boy, do I agree with you, Donna! How about ANIMAL ABUSE like

themselves! People who profit from or engage in dog fighting should go to 
prison for a LONG TIME! I love animals and can't understand why anyone 
would turn our companions into victims like that!  Sue

Did you know that in 1999 Tuesdays With Morrie was released, true store of

as a result of this movie. So now can we bring a lesser known deadly 
disease to the spotlight? I think ALS has enough for a while.
